isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - FANS AND SHUTTERS - OPERATION - Horton Engine Fan Controls With Cummins M11E And N14E

svcproc.title: Horton Engine Fan Controls With Cummins M11E And N14E
svcproc.para: The ECM monitors coolant and intake manifold temperature operating parameters and provides a 0V signal for fan on, or a 12V signal for fan off signal to the 21-way interface connector (312), terminal C. When either the coolant temperature goes above 82.2°C (180°F) or the air intake temperature goes above 65.5°C (150°F), the ECM applies a 0V signal which causes the fan to come on. When boththe coolant temperature goes below 78.3°C (173°F) and the air intake temperature goes below 61.7°C (143°F), the ECM applies a 12V signal which causes the fan to turn off, providing the A/C head pressure is below 275 psi.

The signal is applied to circuit 23D, fan solenoid connector (335) and the normally open fan solenoid. Ground is through connector (335), circuit 23-GA to splice, and circuit 11-GH (11-GU W/N14E) to starter motor ground.

The air conditioner refrigerant pressure switch input is through the 21-way interface connector (312) terminal T, circuit 23C, connector (311) to the normally closed A/C pressure switch. The ground path is through the A/C pressure switch connector (311), circuit 23GB to splice, and circuit 97-G to the common switch ground (pin 10) on ECM connector (320).

The A/C pressure switch senses the refrigerant pressure and if too high (above 275 psi), the switch opens up the circuit. This signals the ECM to de-energize the fan solenoid, which causes the fan to come on.

note.para: Either the coolant or intake manifold temperature sensors, or the A/C pressure switch can turn the fan on, but both the sensors and the A/C pressure switch have to call for the fan to be off before the fan will turn off.
